title: JavaScript library for WhatsApp cloud API
Ask HN: Best self-guided coding interview resources in 2022?
text:
Gearing up for a round of interviews and getting more serious about my prep.

So far I've been sticking with the old standbys:

- Leetcode: Good repository of questions, useful for daily practice, but the educational content leaves a lot to be desired. Some solutions are well written and comprehensive while others are poorly written or incomplete. Had the same experience with HackerRank and similar sites, Leetcode seems to still be the best overall.

- Cracking the Coding Interview: A classic, well written, has a lot of helpful insights, but somewhat out of date.

Looked at Interview Kickstart, but it seems to be a synchronous webinar format, which doesn't fit my learning style. Also, expensive.

What other new resources might I be missing?

Ask HN: Are you cutting back on subscription services?
text:
With a recession looming and inflation already here, are you cutting back on any subscription services?

I have recently gotten rid of Spotify, Amazon Prime, my paid email service, Playstation Network.

I still have Google One (I use Photos, Mobile VPN, switched back to GMail, Google Calendar). I am currently on a trial of Youtube Premium (with Youtube Music) but I probably won't keep it.

I still have iCloud extra storage, Dropbox, GoPro cloud, Netflix and Disney+.

Are our phones becoming too smart to do dumb stuff?
text:
I have noticed that a lot of simple tasks are becoming more difficult to do with smartphones. For example in Android, it's basically impossible to set a countdown timer if the phone is locked without using a voice assistant. Apple might have implemented this specific feature better by allowing users to access the timer through the Control Center. However, iOS's calculator is just too cumbersome to use due its lack of features and lack of decent alternatives. What are your thoughts?

Edit: typo

Ask HN: How are you managing centralized configs at scale?
text:
I have a diverse environment, and varying configs across the various build profiles on various virtual machines.

It feels wrong to have a repo with a bunch of submodules and bash scripts, so I have to ask: How are you managing centralized configs at scale?

Ask HN: What is the best way to benchmark Apple Silicon, Intel and AMD chips?
text: People say Geekbench and Cinebench, two of the most popular benchmarks in the CPU world, are synthetic benchmarks and don't represent real world performance. The question is, how can we benchmark and compare Apple Silicon, Intel and AMD chips that represent real world use the best?
